item.title: Understanding India's Income Segments: Who Constitutes Each Bracket?
item.description:
India’s income distribution is characterized by stark contrasts: while a vast majority earn modest incomes, a small elite enjoys extreme affluence. This article provides an in-depth look at who belongs to each income segment, with recent data and demographic insights.

Major Income Segments in India

1. Less than ₹2 lakh per year

  • Constitutes the Majority: Over 80 crore adults (about 87% of the adult population) earn less than ₹2.9 lakh a year, with a median income around ₹1 lakh[3].
  • Demographics: Rural and urban poor, casual laborers, smallholder farmers, informal sector workers[2][3]. Women and rural citizens are overrepresented.
  • Household Income: Most households earn between ₹12,500 and ₹5,00,000 per year[4].

2. ₹2 lakh – ₹5 lakh per year

  • Lower-middle-income earners and some salaried urban workers.
  • Service sector employees, skilled industrial labor, public and private sector staff.
  • Urbanization is rising, but many remain in smaller towns[2][3][7].

3. ₹5 lakh – ₹15 lakh per year

  • Mid-level professionals and aspiring middle class.
  • Teachers, clerks, nurses, small business owners, public sector staff in metros.
  • Often first-generation graduates and urban migrants[5][7].

4. ₹15 lakh – ₹30 lakh per year

  • “Strivers” of the middle class.
  • Senior professionals, managers, entrepreneurs.
  • Urban, concentrated in metros, educated, tech-enabled[5].

5. ₹30 lakh – ₹2 crore per year

  • Upper-middle class and rich.
  • Senior executives, established business owners, urban concentration in metros and fast-growing tier-2 cities[5][7].

6. More than ₹2 crore per year

  • High net-worth individuals (HNIs), top professionals, business leaders, celebrities.
  • Only about 1.8 million households in 2021; growing segment[5].

7. Greater than ₹25 crore per year

  • Ultra High Net Worth Individuals (UHNWIs).
  • Industrialists, startup unicorn founders, celebrities, sportspeople.
  • Overwhelmingly urban and upper-caste; represents less than 0.1% of population[6][9].
